speaker: User
message: hi, if i am citing from a website with an editor, last name PERSON_LASTNAME_4, that has his/her content cited from a author, how do i go bout my in-text citation?

speaker: User
message: apa-7 citation

speaker: User
message: https://mentalhealthph.org/11-30-21/?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=11-30-21

message: how do i also cite from government website?

message: https://www.ncss.gov.sg/our-stories/detail-page/stories-from-the-heart-nadia-daeng-ncss-singapore

speaker: User
message: do i follow the parenthetical citation, instead of the narrative citation?

speaker: User
message: ohhh okay got it thank you!

speaker: User
message: yep! okay thank you!

speaker: User
message: oh sorry, one more question

speaker: User
message: when i cite from sources, do i have to paraphrase them?

speaker: User
message: ohhh okay got it! thank you!

speaker: Help Desk
message: Hi PERSON_LASTNAME_3 Jun

speaker: Help Desk
message: Would you have the site and the content?

speaker: Help Desk
message:
I'll share an article with you, giving you the detail of how to to cite a secondary source.
https://apastyle.apa.org/style-grammar-guidelines/citations/secondary-sources

speaker: Help Desk
message:
The example goes:

PERSON_LASTNAME_1, 1982, as cited in Lyon, 2014)

speaker: Help Desk
message: The good practice would be to locate the original source and use secondary citations sparingly

speaker: Help Desk
message:
This should work:
https://apastyle.apa.org/style-grammar-guidelines/references/examples/webpage-website-references#3

speaker: Help Desk
message: Usually parenthetical

speaker: Help Desk
message:
The narrative citation works like this:
Author (20XX) argues that his position is really good.

speaker: Help Desk
message: Oh one more note

speaker: Help Desk
message:
When you're citing from the gov website, the version I passed to you works for government websites with the agency as the author.

In other words, if there is an author, eg. NCSS, written by PERSON_FIRSTNAME_1 PERSON_LASTNAME_2, that would be a slightly different style.

speaker: Help Desk
message: For now, I think we have got your queries covered though.

speaker: Help Desk
message: Personally, I would do that

speaker: Help Desk
message: One reason you would want to do that so you will not be accused of plagiarism

speaker: Help Desk
message: The exception would be if you are quoting

speaker: Help Desk
message: Let's say someone says a really important line, and your essay MUST (or you really want that line), then you would have to put the line in quotation mark.

speaker: Help Desk
message: You can then use the narrative style

speaker: Help Desk
message:
E.g.
Great Guy (19XX) said "really clever stuff" and this still holds up today.

speaker: Help Desk
message: Awesome

speaker: Help Desk
message: I'll log out of this chat now. Feel free to start another if you have further queries.

speaker: Help Desk
message: Cheers~
